case_vignette: A 71-year-old male with a past medical history of poorly controlled diabetes and heart transplant is noted to have fevers and a black eschar on the nose on day 41 of hospitalization in the ICU. The patient is intubated and unable to provide history. Nurses report the area was first noticed to be darker and then rapidly expanded. Review of current medications include cyclosporine, tacrolimus, insulin, and broad spectrum antibiotics. Physical examination reveals an extensive dark black, necrotic eschar on the nasal bridge and left nasal sidewall, cheek, and lip with surrounding pink erythema. Oral examinatination reveals black eschars on upper palate. The patient is placed on a regimen of topical silver sulfadiazine and oral ciprofloxacin.
